chunks.text: Hello, my name is Bill Williams and I'm here in the physics department
in the Institute of Fundamental Sciences at Massa University.
Here we have a biomaterials group and we try and look at nature's soft materials and understand
how they're constructed.
So what are soft materials?
When we shake water around it seems pretty obvious it's a liquid.
When we bang on the table it seems pretty obvious that it's a solid.
But think about something like jelly for a moment that you've no doubt all had at parties.
Jelly is more difficult to describe in a material sense.
It might look a bit like a solid if we smack into it fast, but it also wobbles round on
the plate and if we wait a long time we will find that it can flow like a liquid.
It's these sorts of soft materials that in fact a lot of biomaterials are made out of, including
ourselves and plants and lots of things in the world around us.
So what is it that actually makes most of nature's biomaterials soft?
How is it that they're like this?
It's because they tend to be made up out of long strings of molecules called polymers,
a bit like this chain.
The molecules I'm interested in actually are small components of sugars
which are actually stuck together one after another,
and these make long chain molecules that might be millions of units long.
These chain molecules have a large degree of flexibility.
When we stick these together to make materials,
we get things like rubber and things which are what we call visco elastic,
things which are like solids and liquids,
or to me and you, gloopy and soft materials.
We're interested in the properties of soft materials
and how these properties depend on the polymers
from which the materials are made.
But how do we measure the properties of the materials at all?
You might think we can just take a lump of the material
and shake it around a bit.
But what we've been doing here at Massey recently
is developing a technique called microreology.
Here we take small fluorescent beads
and actually put them inside the material. We look how these beads move around inside the
material and from that we infer something of the properties. Inside this flask
here I have a slightly viscous solution and inside it some tiny beads which you can
see are glowing. These beads are a small size. Typically
there's a thousand of them in one millimeter. I'm going to take some of these beads now in
this material and actually put it onto a microscope slide. I'm going to pass this over to
Ramarik. Here's going to have a look in the microscope.
So what is it that we can actually see under the microscope?
This apparatus here is a fluorescence microscope.
On the surface of the little beads, there is a chemical which, when illuminated,
actually makes the particles glow.
And this allows us to pick them up with good sensitivity and actually see what are they doing in there.
This data is captured by a camera and taken into a computer.
This allows us to film images and also the time course of the motion.
You can see here that the particles aren't just stationary.
They're actually jiggling around just because of the temperature of the room.
This is akin to Brownian motion, the same thing that forms some of Einstein's important work in 1905.
From this motion you can understand now how we can actually probe the properties of the soft materials.
When this motion is very fast and the particles move far, the material is very much just like water.
If the particles can't move far and they can just jiggle around like this,
it's much more like a solid elastic material.
And so it's by using these motions of the particles
that we're actually able to get materials information
on what these soft materials are like.
So these are new and exciting techniques
which are developing here at Massey,
which we can use to look at the properties of soft biomaterials. We aim to couple this information with actually information
about the polymer structures to understand how nature uses different polymers to make materials
with different properties. Ultimately, this will illuminate nature's design rules about our own
tissues, about plants and about the world around us. And who knows?
By looking how nature does things, maybe we can think about constructing materials in more
intelligent ways too.
